title: 114_hr5243
content: Appropriations are made for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2016, for the Department of Health and Human Services, specifically for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's cdc-wide activities and program support. $170,000,000 is allocated for CDC-Wide Activities and Program Support to prevent, prepare for, and respond to Zika virus domestically and internationally. The funds can be used for purchasing products deposited in the Strategic National Stockpile and for official motor vehicles in foreign countries. The Director of CDC will determine the appropriate use of funds as per section 317S of the PHS Act. Transfers of funds appropriated in this paragraph are allowed. The Director of CDC may transfer funds appropriated in the paragraph for Zika virus-related patient care activities, including prenatal care, delivery care, postpartum care, newborn health assessments, and care for infants with special health care needs. Up to $50,000,000 can be transferred to the Health Resources and Services Administration for the Maternal and Child Health Services Block Grant Program. This transfer authority is in addition to any other transfer authority provided by law and funds may be awarded regardless of section 502 of the Social Security Act. The funds transferred under section 502 of the Social Security Act can be awarded for special projects of regional and national significance to authorized entities, with a restriction on using the funds to make grants to other organizations or individuals. The National Institutes of Health, specifically the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, is involved in the transfer of funds for special projects of regional and national significance to authorized entities. The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases is allocated an additional $230,000,000 for the development of Zika virus vaccines. The funds can be transferred to other NIH accounts as needed. This amount is designated as an emergency requirement and will be available until September 30, 2016. Office of the Secretary oversees the public health and social services emergency fund, including fund transfers. $103,000,000 is allocated for the Public Health and Social Services Emergency Fund to develop countermeasures and vaccines for Zika virus, domestically and internationally. Funds can be used for purchasing necessary medical supplies and administrative activities. Security countermeasures may also be procured with these funds. Funds appropriated in this paragraph may be deposited in the Strategic National Stockpile or transferred to another fund authorized by the PHS Act. The amount designated as an emergency requirement by Congress can only be used if the President confirms and notifies Congress. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must notify the Committees on Appropriations 15 days in advance before using funds appropriated in this title, unless there is a substantial risk to human health or welfare. In case of a waiver, notification must be provided within 3 days with an explanation of the emergency circumstances. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must provide a consolidated report on the proposed uses of funds appropriated by this title within 30 days of enactment, with updates every 30 days until all funds are expended. Sec. 103. Up to $500,000 from CDC funds will be transferred to the Office of Inspector General for oversight, and another $500,000 will be allocated to the Comptroller General for oversight of funded activities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must consult with the Committees on Appropriations before using these funds. For "Diplomatic and Consular Programs", an additional $9,100,000 is allocated for medical evacuations and response efforts related to the Zika virus until September 30, 2016. This amount is designated as an emergency requirement by Congress. The United States Agency for International Development has allocated $10,000,000 for operating expenses to support response efforts related to the Zika virus. This amount is designated as an emergency requirement by Congress. Additionally, funds have been appropriated for global health programs under bilateral economic assistance. $100,000,000 allocated for global health programs to prevent, prepare for, and respond to Zika virus internationally. Sec. 201 authorizes funds for medical evacuation costs and transfers within the Diplomatic and Consular Programs budget. Transfer authorities granted are in addition to existing laws. Congress designates transferred amounts as emergency requirements. The President can designate and transmit funds for specific purposes, with the option to transfer unused funds back to the original appropriation if not needed. Notification and reporting requirements for funds appropriated under this title mandate that the Secretary of State or the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development notify the Committees on Appropriations in writing at least 15 days in advance of any obligation. Waivers can be granted in cases of substantial risk to human health or welfare, with notification required within 3 days after the action. Emergency circumstances must be explained in any notification provided under a waiver. The Secretary of State, in consultation with the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, must submit a consolidated report to the Committees on Appropriations within 30 days of the enactment of this Act detailing the proposed uses of funds appropriated under this title. The report must be updated every 30 days until all funds are fully expended. Sec. 204. Up to $500,000 transferred to the Office of Inspector General for oversight of activities supported with funds appropriated by this title. Another $500,000 made available to the Comptroller General for oversight purposes. The State and the Comptroller General must consult with the Committees on Appropriations before using allocated funds. TITLE III - GENERAL PROVISIONS--THIS ACT (including rescissions of funds) Sec. 301 of the Act rescinds $352,100,000 from unobligated balances of appropriations under specific titles. The Office of Management and Budget Director will determine the accounts and amounts for the rescission after consulting with relevant Secretaries. A report detailing the amounts rescinded by agency, account, and program must be transmitted to the Committees on Appropriations within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The "Zika Response Appropriations Act, 2016" rescinds $270,000,000 from unobligated balances in the Nonrecurring expenses fund. Additional appropriations for fiscal year 2016 are subject to the requirements of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016. The "Zika Response Appropriations Act, 2016" was passed by the House of Representatives on May 18, 2016. Karen L. Haas attested to the passing of the act.
